This trilogy is not a game, it's an experience. 
I'm Commander Shepard, and this is my favourite game on the Steam store.

Mass Effect is unlike any other franchise out there. Most other sci-fi games set in space solely focus on colonization, resource extraction/crafting, or are so far removed from the reality we are accustomed to it becomes more fiction than science. In a sense there is a familiarity to Mass Effect, not only in its narrative-driven design, but in the universe and its characters. 

The lore throughout the games remained so, so, captivating. Whether it was through datapads, missions, or retroactive dialogue based on your decisions in previous games, the environments were beautifully designed to fully immerse the player within the Mass Effect universe. It doesn't try to simplify concepts, and instead demands your attention to the experiences you have throughout the games. I believe that respects the player's intelligence, and makes for stronger mental connections to the lore.

Frankly I cannot recommend this highly enough. I now see why there were always fervent fans of the original trilogy. There is so much replayability to be had, and with each game delivering around 40 hours of content, you will get your moneys worth MANY times over.

[h1] The brightest star in the action RPG firmament [/h1]

I‚Äôm ashamed to admit that I‚Äôm one of those people who never played Mass Effect before the Legendary Edition came out. When you‚Äôre young(er), other genres appeal more to your tastes, I was into RTSs, hack and slash games and the occasional RPG, so a story rich, choice driven, decision and consequence type of game, even with some RPG elements, didn‚Äôt seem like the kind of thing I wanted to immerse myself in or ‚Äúwaste time‚Äù with.
I‚Äôm no stranger to BioWare‚Äôs work, I‚Äôm a fan of Dragon Age, SWTOR, and even today I still play Neverwinter Nights, but for some reason Mass Effect never piqued my interest.

I was so wrong‚Ä¶

I can‚Äôt speak for the legacy versions of Mass Effect, but with the Legendary Edition (LE), all I can say is that this feels like the way to play it, or rather, the way it was meant to be experienced all along. The original trilogy released between 2007 and 2012, built fully on Unreal Engine 3 with all its capacities and limitations, and in 2021 LE arrived still running on UE3 but with a plethora of upgrades in lighting, textures, QoL, models, shaders, performance and so on.
So let‚Äôs get one thing straight, LE is, in the true sense of the word, a deep and thorough remaster, not a remake.

Regarding graphics, by today‚Äôs standards, even with the upgrades, it has aged, and the limitations of UE3 do show. Even so, it‚Äôs still a beautiful game to experience. Starting with Mass Effect 1, you notice that some mostly interior locations are almost identical to one another, the only thing that changes is the colour palette and textures, and the lack of asset variety is evident. This aspect is mitigated in Mass Effect 2, and further improved in Mass Effect 3.
But overall, even with these ‚Äúdownsides‚Äù and I put it in quotes because I don‚Äôt consider it one, but some people might, the visuals are enjoyable and credible, and the simple touch of using Mass Effect 3‚Äôs character models and details as the base for all three games was brilliant, visually consolidating the entire story and making the trilogy feel more cohesive.

This is, of course, a matter of opinion. Even with LE, it‚Äôs still a four year old upgrade of an eighteen year old game, but I would rather play something with dated or old school graphics that keeps me entertained and immersed than a game with nearly lifelike visuals that feels void of emotion and purpose. And nowadays there‚Äôs no shortage of titles that chase graphical fidelity but fail to connect or captivate the player.

In the sound department, the cast of voice actors is blessed with legends like Lance Henriksen, Keith David, Steve Blum, Seth Green and Raphael Sbarge, among many others, and all of them deliver performances that bring characters to life with such feeling, gravitas and emotion that very few games possess.
As for the soundtrack, Sam Hulick and Jack Wall did an incredible job dressing the galaxy with music that ranges from ethereal and ambient while exploring to synth and hard techno when wandering around places like Afterlife or Purgatory, and even some truly epic scores for when you do epic things. No spoilers.

Gameplay wise, I often feel like I‚Äôm playing three completely different games from ME1 to ME3. You see concepts evolving, features being added or removed, systems being streamlined. For example, in ME1 you had to manage inventory and equip companions one by one through lockers, something later improved in ME2 and ME3 where you equip as needed right before missions. The only management becomes choosing which upgrades to use and which armour pieces look best on your Shepard.
Another thing is movement and motion. From ME1 to ME3, you will notice a lot of differences, especially during firefights. Duck, cover, flank, you‚Äôll need all of that.
Oh, and starting from ME2, don‚Äôt bother looking for a walk toggle. There isn‚Äôt one.

One of the most memorable aspects of Mass Effect is the depth and richness of its universe, the races, cultures, values, beliefs and traditions. From some of these races come your companions, characters larger than life with their own stories and fears that you uncover along the way. The narrative you find yourself in is intricate, full of twists and revelations, and your companions grow with you. No doubt you‚Äôll feel closer to some characters than others, but trust me, take the time to know them all. You‚Äôll be amazed by the complexity and roundness of their personalities and stories.

Now for some advice: ME1 > Liara and ME2 and ME3 > Tali.

To finish this review, and to sum up my shame, I‚Äôm reviewing this jewel of a trilogy in 2025, meaning I‚Äôm 18 years late. But I genuinely feel this deserves a review, even a late one, for all the laughs, tears, wholesome moments, intricate narrative, memorable characters and the masterpiece of a story it gave me.
If I could go back in time and meet my younger self, I‚Äôd kick him so hard for skipping this that he‚Äôd still feel it today. No matter what I write, I‚Äôll never do justice to the masterpiece this trilogy is. You have to play it to feel it.

I‚Äôve always loved space, the galaxy, and anything that resembles Dragon Age, so naturally I love this trilogy. I‚Äôll review them in order.

Mass Effect 1:
You can immediately tell it‚Äôs a 2007 game. It has a unique aura for its genre: it‚Äôs a game about other worlds and galaxies where you‚Äôre thrown onto these remote planets WITHOUT A MARKER, WITHOUT HELP. You go there and you have to figure out what to do ON YOUR OWN. You can‚Äôt afford to skip dialogue or ignore your journal, otherwise you‚Äôll have no idea what‚Äôs going on. Many times you find yourself on a mission with absolutely no clue whether you‚Äôre going in the right direction or the wrong one.
The atmosphere is incredible and truly makes you feel like you‚Äôre actually there, like you‚Äôre really lost in space. Gameplay-wise it‚Äôs behind the others, but it‚Äôs light-years ahead when it comes to the emotions it makes you feel while playing.

Mass Effect 2:
Obviously the best of the three, and definitely one of the greatest RPGs in history. We all know why and we all know how, so I won‚Äôt drag this out. I just want to say that I LOVED the variety of missions‚Äîespecially the final one.

Mass Effect 3:
The game was HARSHLY criticized for its ending, but I think the ending is actually the only strong point of the game. What fits better in a game than a finale where you can choose to end the universe? Or reset it? Nothing‚Äîpure chaos, pure anarchy.
The problem is everything that comes before it: boring missions where you just go somewhere and shoot everyone, unlike ME2 where every mission is different and genuinely tells you something. It takes everything good about Mass Effect 2 and simply brings it back here.
Basically, the strengths of this game come from ME2‚Äîbecause they‚Äôre all borrowed

Mass Effect is a game that I will always remember fondly and not only because I used to play the first game on an Xbox 360 that was so loud it looked like it was going to re, enter the atmosphere while I was staring at a tube TV. Mass Effect stayed with me because it was the first game that made me think that my choices had an impact... until 2012, when BioWare gently came to me and said, "Hmm, not really. Here are your three colors, have fun." 

Mass Effect 1 
Playing this again with the Legendary Edition is a bit like bringing an old photo album back from the attic, except if the people in the photos were smuggling assault rifles and sometimes went through the furniture. The improvement is stunning. Now, Eden Prime really is a paradise instead of just a low, res screensaver. Shepard still moves like a refrigerator with legs, but that's definitely one of the things that makes the game so lovable. It's the timeless one: the Reapers mystery, the awkward elevator rides, the Mako making every planet a sort of low, gravity trampoline park. Just right. 

Mass Effect 2
just hits different. The Legendary Edition makes everything look and feel even better smoother, flashier, like you‚Äôre watching a top-tier sci-fi movie you get to control. Every character stands out. The missions? Can't ask for more. Then you‚Äôve got those loyalty quests that mess with your head and your heart. If Mass Effect 1 feels like coming home, Mass Effect 2 is that first taste of independence your own place in the city, sitting back and thinking, ‚ÄúYeah, this is the life.‚Äù 

Mass Effect 3
There is a lot to like in ME3, the combat is awesome, the characters go through incredible changes, and the final arc could have been absolutely amazing. However the ending‚Ä¶ Oh yes, the ending: the point where BioWare took all my choices, relationships, sacrifices, and hours of meticulous Paragon/Renegade moral philosophy, mixed them in a cosmic way, and delivered it in three slightly different "Oops" colors. 

It was not only disappointing, it felt like the developers invited me to a birthday party, gave me a beautifully wrapped present, and inside there was a note saying, "The real choices were the friends you made along the way. By the way, please pick a color now." 

Nonetheless, even ME3 is a bit more brilliant in the Legendary Edition, although no amount of remastering can completely take away my trauma from the star child‚Äôs PowerPoint presentation at the end. 

Final Verdict 
Mass Effect Legendary Edition isn't just a visual upgrade; it's a passport to another time. It reintroduces the delight, the amazement, the thrill of being in charge of the Normandy‚Ä¶ and yes, the disappointment of realizing that after three games of making choices that affect the whole galaxy, your ultimate destiny would be determined by a glowing space toddler handing you a multiple, choice test. 

Honestly? After all that..... I'd still do it. In a heartbeat. The journey is simply that awesome. 

In fact, the Legendary Edition is the impact that we have always known Mass Effect is not one game, or even three, it is a feeling. A feeling of heroism, camaraderie, heartbreak, and at times, shouting ‚ÄúTHAT‚ÄôS NOT HOW MY SHEPARD WOULD ACT‚Äù at your TV. 

10/10. Would romance Garrus again.

Performance is great, and bugs are very minimal. Among the trilogy, I only encountered one bug in ME3 where if you save and quit after convincing the Eclipse to work with Aria, Captain Bailey will never contact you to complete the quest. You can mitigate this with the Trilogy Save Editor, however, and doing so took me no more than ten minutes.

ME1 has been given a new lease of life with the quality of life updates to its inventory, powers, achievements and progression. I recommend the new Level 30 Trilogy  style levelling system to get the most out of your builds.

ME2 is still superb, with one of the most daring intros in videogames and a bolstered roster of anti-heroes you can't help but care for by the end, where the game culminates in one of the most tense, heart-pounding and consequential finales in all of videogames.

And ME3 feels amazing on a mouse, wow. It was my least fav of the trilogy on console, but on PC I appreciate its combat system so much more. Story:
The story of the Mass Effect Trilogy (ME for short) follows the same path, trying to save humanity, and space itself, from an inevitable invasion. Although the main objective of each game is different, it all comes together to form a unique and spectacular storyline across the three games, one of the most memorable I‚Äôve ever played.

If that wasn‚Äôt enough, the player has a lot to say about how the story goes with the constant choices they make, which actually impact the narrative, instead of giving you the illusion of choice. Depending on what you‚Äôve done or what you say in certain dialogues, some characters may die or live, among other consequences. Even the more meaningless quest you think won‚Äôt alter anything may cause a character to appear or not in the next game.

And very important to say if you didn‚Äôt know already: your character‚Äôs choices and design goes from one game to the next one. This means that it will feel like one unique game, one single story, divided into three acts. Romanced a character in one of the games? They‚Äôll be there, waiting for you, on the next one.


Gameplay:
Mass Effect‚Äôs combat is based on a 3rd person shooter, with a large amount of weapons you can choose from (pistols, sniper rifle, shotgun‚Ä¶), while using yours and your crewmates‚Äô abilities to win each battle. A lot of people enjoy the tactical side of this system, while I prefer to go sniping everything I see while they use their abilities on their own, which is a thing you can activate, at least in ME2 and 3. So you can play it as you see fit.

Characters:
This one is one of the other aspects of gaming where ME shines again. The trilogy grants us access to a ton of original characters, with their own individual personalities, likes, stories, quests, and abilities. You‚Äôll surely fall in love with at least some of the characters, and you‚Äôll hate others with such a burning passion‚Ä¶ They definitely feel real, almost all of the time.

You‚Äôll also get to know your crew deeply if you want to, as you can approach them and talk to them any moment you want, and they‚Äôll have something to talk about most of the time. (ME 2 DLC characters, Kasumi and Zaeed, together with the ME3 crew, have stuff to say, but you won‚Äôt always be able to have a conversation with them). Anyways, the ME Trilogy has an amazing cast, not only your crew, but some NPCs as well, and might have some of the best companions in games. It also has some mid ones, but most of them are incredibly written during the entire trilogy. Not only that, but you‚Äôll also be seeing characters from a past installment in the other games, which fills you with an incredible joy. And, sometimes, they‚Äôll be joining your squad again.

Music:

I‚Äôm not an expert on music, and while I‚Äôm playing I don‚Äôt really pay attention to it anyways, so take this with a grain of salt, BUT I think this game has some amazing music at some scenes and cutscenes, I remember specially at the ME1 finale.


Extra categories.
Graphics: Not as realistic as other games, but enjoyable anyways, do not look outdated at all, at least to me.

Locations: Again, another aspect Bioware‚Äôs game shines at. Every planet you explore is unique, with unique landscapes, skies, color palettes‚Ä¶ I remember entering a planet and seeing an enormous red sun in front of me. It was gorgeous.

Worldbuilding: The games have a lot of ways to let you dig deep into the universe‚Äôs lore: you can ask characters about it, or you can look up the Codex, which has, and I mean it,  A LOT of information about the different races, characters, and locations, among others. You‚Äôll be able to change a bit the hair and eyes, your face, and that‚Äôs it, even though there aren‚Äôt a lot of good hair options either. Still, I, a person who loves to creates character and was pretty disappointed at seeing the CC, managed to make a Shepard I enjoyed.

Mass Effect did [i]not[/i] withstand the test of time.

I have no idea what they remastered, because the game is exactly as I remember it from 2 decades ago. The Legendary Edition includes all DLCs, but I didn't see anything beyond the vanilla game after playing ~75% of ME1 (that's where I finally stopped, because I was beyond bored. I didn't even bother starting ME2 and 3). 

I remembered ME as having one of the best stories I've ever seen in a video game. After playing it again, I think it's a rather simple one rather poorly told. 

You make some choices here and there, yes, but they are binary and you don't have to wonder about their consequences, because the game immediately tells you the moral outcome of your pick by awarding you Paragon or Renegade points. So, your options are always the same: to do what the game considers "good," or what it considers "bad."

Surveying planets is boring and pointless. Landing on them is much worse, because doing so takes you to a large empty area with a bumpy terrain that is quite annoying to navigate with your bouncy and weirdly-controlled 6-wheeler. If you bother exploring them thoroughly, all you'll find is money, a few sad items, and/or your worst nightmare: a copy-pasted location. And I'm not even talking about some nice, complex place; no, I'm talking about a few interconnected square rooms filled with nothing but boxes -- and always the same 5 or so different boxes, because these are pretty much all the props available in the game.

Combat is dull, consisting in your weapon overheating while you fire at bullet-sponges that move illogically. Having 2 squad mates joining you in battle is cool, but they act stupidly and frequently get in your way.

Your characters have skill trees, but these are boring and uninspired. Also, you get a ton of skill points, likely enough to get 100% of skills on everyone (no strategic building required whatsoever). 

Items are dull as well. Weapons' stats consist in variations of damage/heat-sink/accuracy, armors' in variations of defence/shield/biotic or tech defence. That's all. The only interesting thing about items is that weapons and armors have slots in which you can install some mods, adding bonuses to them. That's nice, but the mods themselves are nearly as uninspired as everything else in the game.

All maps are small, all spaces tight, everything linear. The game's level design is the worst and laziest I think I've ever seen.

To wrap it all in a paper bag and set it on fire on your porch, Mass Effect requires EA's platform to be installed on your computer, and for it to run every time you start the game. It's been quite fun replaying the trilogy with updated graphics... but I feel like this was an incredibly low effort attempt at a Remaster.

For starters, the combat is every bit as tedious as the original trilogy-- especially ME2. All enemies act like bullet sponges, even on the easier difficulties. Combat isn't hard, it just gets frustrating having to empty a clip of 30-50 rounds into every single enemy. This is something that can literally be tweaked in a matter of seconds and wouldn't have taken more than a day to perfect. The devs just couldn't be bothered to do so. Squad powers and biotics (if you play adept) are extremely unreliable too, just like the originals. They fire off at weird angles and hardly ever behave as expected.

However, most people-- myself included-- play for the characters and the story... but even that didn't manage to see any reasonable improvement. In fact, I've actually had a couple of errors that I never experienced with the original 3 games: and those are problems with the relationship system. In ME1, I was friendly with Liara, told her there wasn't anything romantic between us, and romanced Ashley... but somehow I ended up getting the Liara ending. I thought maybe I made a mistake and carried on... then, in the second game, I romanced Tali (as always) but acted friendly with Jack and told her there was nothing romantic between us... I then somehow got thrown into the Jack romance, locked out of the Tali romance ("end things with Jack", which I couldn't do because Jack refused to talk to me), and then when I met with Liara she said she was "tossed aside for a tattooed woman with anger issues"-- again, I never even started the romance with Jack, I started it with Tali.

For me, this is by far the worst issue because it means you have to frequently reload the game and time each interaction carefully. It wasn't a problem in the originals, so I don't see why it is suddenly a problem in the remaster. It's clearly something to do with the relationship points behind the scenes.

Speaking of Tali... the replacement photo of Tali still feels like a massive cop-out. There's clearly been no thought put into it whatsoever, which feels incredibly frustrating when the rest of the world-building has been so masterfully done. It's not just about this one character, it's about an entire race of people who are central to the plot... it should have been a massive reveal, but instead it was just thrown in there without a care in the world. Honestly, I'd rather they just deleted that scene than to try and fix one bad photoshop job with another. Her mouth isn't even close to the filter on her mask, it just looks weird. You can find dozens of speculative fan art of the Quarians which do a much better job of imagining their look.

Lastly, all of these issues would have been much easier to fix if console commands or mods were easy to use. I have no idea why the devs went out of their way to put so many roadblocks in the way to prevent players from doing these things, but it's just another reason to find this game disappointing.

If you have the originals-- download some graphics mods. 

If you don't, wait until this game goes on at least 70% sale, and hopefully you won't be too disappointed. I, unfortunately, was.

In 2007, Mass Effect 1 launched alongside Assassin‚Äôs Creed, Modern Warfare, The Witcher, Space Rangers 2, and Overlord.
In 2010, Mass Effect 2 released in the same year as Mafia II, Metro 2033, Fallout: New Vegas, Brotherhood, and Bad Company 2.

Everyone already knows the positives of the trilogy ‚Äî hundreds of reviews have written them out in detail, so I won‚Äôt repeat them. But honestly:

ME1 is visually barren, mechanically empty, and painfully outdated ‚Äî even by the standards of its own release year.
ME2 fixes some issues, but still looks and plays rough.
ME3 finally shows better visual direction and game design, but even then it can‚Äôt escape the core problems of the series.

And even with nostalgia ‚Äî even after multiple playthroughs ‚Äî I have to admit:
these games aged terribly.
The gameplay is weak, the combat often frustrating, the visuals unimpressive, and Legendary Edition simply cannot fix the wasted potential of what should have been a defining space opera.

Bioware were always praised as ‚Äúgeniuses‚Äù and ‚ÄúRPG legends,‚Äù but in truth they only ever excelled at worldbuilding and storytelling. Gameplay? Interesting mechanics? Engaging combat? The original three games are masterpieces, probably Bioware's peak, even the much maligned Mass Effect 3. You can definitely see the quality start to suffer badly in ME3, and why it (and arguably Dragon Age Inquisition) were the last Bioware games worth playing despite both being more than a decade old at this point.

Unfortunately, like everything Bioware and indeed EA have made in the past decade the remastered legendary edition manages to be a low effort, poorly done disappointment. Mass Effect 1 is the only game that can even really claim to be a "remaster" in the trilogy, with the visuals and previously very janky UI having been significantly rehauled. Brain dead AI and issues with inventory management from the original ME1 unfortunately remain.

ME2 and ME3 on the other hand are both buggier and jankier than the original games were when they came out 15 years ago. Minimal improvement has been made, there is no DLSS or even any decent anti aliasing options so those games will be full of jaggies unless you force anti aliasing elsewhere.

The fact that the game relies on the EA launcher to load means that a decent portion of the time it simply won't start up properly, forcing you to dig through the task manager and manually shut down the EA app process to get the game to even boot up properly.

Basically the legendary edition is a great reminder of how Bioware used to make phenomenal games, with a low effort remaster showing us that they unfortunately no longer can deliver. The Mass Effect trilogy deserved a proper high effort remaster or remake, like we have seen recently with Oblivion Remastered and with the RE4, Dead Space and Demon's Souls remakes. Unfortunately this is anything but that.

[h1]Unlike Fine Wine[/h1]

Mass Effect did [i]not[/i] withstand the test of time.

I have no idea what they remastered, because the game is exactly as I remember it from 2 decades ago. The Legendary Edition includes all DLCs, but I didn't see anything beyond the vanilla game after playing ~75% of ME1 (that's where I finally stopped, because I was beyond bored. I didn't even bother starting ME2 and 3). 

I remembered ME as having one of the best stories I've ever seen in a video game. After playing it again, I think it's a rather simple one rather poorly told. 

You make some choices here and there, yes, but they are binary and you don't have to wonder about their consequences, because the game immediately tells you the moral outcome of your pick by awarding you Paragon or Renegade points. So, your options are always the same: to do what the game considers "good," or what it considers "bad."

Surveying planets is boring and pointless. Landing on them is much worse, because doing so takes you to a large empty area with a bumpy terrain that is quite annoying to navigate with your bouncy and weirdly-controlled 6-wheeler. If you bother exploring them thoroughly, all you'll find is money, a few sad items, and/or your worst nightmare: a copy-pasted location. And I'm not even talking about some nice, complex place; no, I'm talking about a few interconnected square rooms filled with nothing but boxes -- and always the same 5 or so different boxes, because these are pretty much all the props available in the game.

Combat is dull, consisting in your weapon overheating while you fire at bullet-sponges that move illogically. Having 2 squad mates joining you in battle is cool, but they act stupidly and frequently get in your way.

Your characters have skill trees, but these are boring and uninspired. Also, you get a ton of skill points, likely enough to get 100% of skills on everyone (no strategic building required whatsoever). 

Items are dull as well. Weapons' stats consist in variations of damage/heat-sink/accuracy, armors' in variations of defence/shield/biotic or tech defence. That's all. The only interesting thing about items is that weapons and armors have slots in which you can install some mods, adding bonuses to them. That's nice, but the mods themselves are nearly as uninspired as everything else in the game.

All maps are small, all spaces tight, everything linear. The game's level design is the worst and laziest I think I've ever seen.

To wrap it all in a paper bag and set it on fire on your porch, Mass Effect requires EA's platform to be installed on your computer, and for it to run every time you start the game. After it just refused to open twice in a row as I was about to force myself to play the game for a few more minutes, I finally gave up on it. 

In short, ME is terribly [i]dated[/i]. I thought it was a classic, but no -- it was just once good, in a time when there was simply nothing better. All the charm it had when initially released is gone. Now, it's just an embarrassing example of how awful [i]everything[/i] in games was 20 years ago.

It's been quite fun replaying the trilogy with updated graphics... but I feel like this was an incredibly low effort attempt at a Remaster.

For starters, the combat is every bit as tedious as the original trilogy-- especially ME2. All enemies act like bullet sponges, even on the easier difficulties. Combat isn't hard, it just gets frustrating having to empty a clip of 30-50 rounds into every single enemy. This is something that can literally be tweaked in a matter of seconds and wouldn't have taken more than a day to perfect. The devs just couldn't be bothered to do so. Squad powers and biotics (if you play adept) are extremely unreliable too, just like the originals. They fire off at weird angles and hardly ever behave as expected.

However, most people-- myself included-- play for the characters and the story... but even that didn't manage to see any reasonable improvement. In fact, I've actually had a couple of errors that I never experienced with the original 3 games: and those are problems with the relationship system. In ME1, I was friendly with Liara, told her there wasn't anything romantic between us, and romanced Ashley... but somehow I ended up getting the Liara ending. I thought maybe I made a mistake and carried on... then, in the second game, I romanced Tali (as always) but acted friendly with Jack and told her there was nothing romantic between us... I then somehow got thrown into the Jack romance, locked out of the Tali romance ("end things with Jack", which I couldn't do because Jack refused to talk to me), and then when I met with Liara she said she was "tossed aside for a tattooed woman with anger issues"-- again, I never even started the romance with Jack, I started it with Tali.

For me, this is by far the worst issue because it means you have to frequently reload the game and time each interaction carefully. It wasn't a problem in the originals, so I don't see why it is suddenly a problem in the remaster. It's clearly something to do with the relationship points behind the scenes.

Speaking of Tali... the replacement photo of Tali still feels like a massive cop-out. There's clearly been no thought put into it whatsoever, which feels incredibly frustrating when the rest of the world-building has been so masterfully done. It's not just about this one character, it's about an entire race of people who are central to the plot... it should have been a massive reveal, but instead it was just thrown in there without a care in the world. Honestly, I'd rather they just deleted that scene than to try and fix one bad photoshop job with another. Her mouth isn't even close to the filter on her mask, it just looks weird. You can find dozens of speculative fan art of the Quarians which do a much better job of imagining their look.

Lastly, all of these issues would have been much easier to fix if console commands or mods were easy to use. I have no idea why the devs went out of their way to put so many roadblocks in the way to prevent players from doing these things, but it's just another reason to find this game disappointing.

If you have the originals-- download some graphics mods. 

If you don't, wait until this game goes on at least 70% sale, and hopefully you won't be too disappointed. I, unfortunately, was.
